00:16:51.270 --> 00:16:56.010

00:16:56.010 --> 00:16:58.461

00:16:58.461 --> 00:17:01.270

00:17:01.270 --> 00:17:04.324

00:17:39.180 --> 00:17:41.381

00:17:41.381 --> 00:17:44.703

00:17:54.792 --> 00:17:55.500
>> Yes, exactly.

00:17:55.500 --> 00:17:58.420

00:18:02.040 --> 00:18:05.020

Command two.

episodes.description:
In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look at using conditional
logic statements in bash scripts. Here they finish their discussion by going
over compound testing; employing boolean logic as well as when to use double
parenthesis(()) and/or double brackets[[]]. Finally they show you the case
conditional statement, both its format and functions.
episodes.title: Conditional Statements Part 3

00:05:05.400 --> 00:05:09.830

00:05:13.250 --> 00:05:17.210
This is what let's it know that

97
00:05:17.210 --> 00:05:20.930
This and this together.

98
00:05:20.930 --> 00:05:25.220
If both of these statements are true,
then we will do something.

99
00:05:25.220 --> 00:05:29.780
Then we will jump down to the then

00:05:29.780 --> 00:05:36.210

00:05:36.210 --> 00:05:38.040

00:05:46.491 --> 00:05:51.980

00:05:54.100 --> 00:05:57.450

00:05:59.650 --> 00:06:02.440

00:06:02.440 --> 00:06:04.610

I just know that's how it's

00:06:20.200 --> 00:06:24.230
The two ampersands t ogether let's it

00:06:24.230 --> 00:06:30.160
And we're gonna compare two
sets of comparisons together.

117
00:06:30.160 --> 00:06:33.280
If both ring true,
then we move on from there.

118
00:06:33.280 --> 00:06:36.000
So I don't know if it's like negation.

119
00:06:36.000 --> 00:06:39.130
I don't think it's like negation,
we're not negating anything.

120
00:06:39.130 --> 00:06:40.630
>> It's just that that's how it is.

00:06:40.630 --> 00:06:43.390

00:06:57.120 --> 00:07:00.376

00:07:00.376 --> 00:07:05.070

00:07:05.070 --> 00:07:07.751
So I'll do ./com, what is it?

130
00:07:07.751 --> 00:07:09.160
compound_testing.sh.

00:07:09.160 --> 00:07:13.680
You'll notice it does Success

00:07:13.680 --> 00:07:15.990

00:07:31.100 --> 00:07:32.080

00:07:32.080 --> 00:07:37.550

00:07:37.550 --> 00:07:41.910

139
00:07:41.910 --> 00:07:46.610
Insert in here, we'll just hash that guy
out, bring that guy to the forefront,

00:07:46.610 --> 00:07:47.660
Esc, write, quit.

141
00:07:49.170 --> 00:07:49.960
Run that guy again.

142
00:07:49.960 --> 00:07:51.734
And look at that, we get our Failure.

143
00:07:51.734 --> 00:07:57.130
Because now, remember both sides of

144
00:07:57.130 --> 00:07:59.441
If they don't, You're gonna have

145
00:07:59.441 --> 00:08:02.374
It's not gonna run the expected

00:08:02.374 --> 00:08:05.400
Now sometimes that's okay.

147
00:08:07.040 --> 00:08:09.070
It's not okay if you use the ampersands,

148
00:08:09.070 --> 00:08:12.880
Sometimes you don't care whether or
not both of them ring true.

149
00:08:12.880 --> 00:08:16.170
I just wanna say if this or
this one rings true.

150
00:08:16.170 --> 00:08:19.900
Either, as long as one of them rings true,
I'm good.

151
00:08:19.900 --> 00:08:22.807
And you can move on to what I expected
to do which is in that then part of

152
00:08:22.807 --> 00:08:23.526
the statement.

153
00:08:23.526 --> 00:08:27.606
And then if none of that rings true,
so with this logical or,

154
00:08:27.606 --> 00:08:30.895
which is this guy right here,
this double pipe.

155
00:08:30.895 --> 00:08:34.098
We've seen the pipe before

00:08:34.098 --> 00:08:36.716

157
00:08:36.716 --> 00:08:43.270
This is the double pipe that lets
you know that I want this or this.

158
00:08:43.270 --> 00:08:44.952
Either of these statements will ring true.

159
00:08:44.952 --> 00:08:49.615
Then, do the commands that I've given you,

160
00:08:49.615 --> 00:08:53.070
else, run my catch all, right?

161
00:08:53.070 --> 00:08:55.700
So, I've got var1, [INAUDIBLE] goes on.

162
00:08:55.700 --> 00:08:58.350
Basically, the same script right above it.

163
00:08:58.350 --> 00:09:04.710
We're gonna comment that out,
and uncomment this guy out.

164
00:09:06.740 --> 00:09:09.410
Here we go and uncomment that.

165
00:09:09.410 --> 00:09:14.317
So now, if our var1 equals 1,
or if var2 equals 20,

00:09:14.317 --> 00:09:21.740

167
00:09:21.740 --> 00:09:26.270
So before it was our double ends, it was
our logical ending, both had to be true.

168
00:09:26.270 --> 00:09:29.990
With the or, it's either or,
hence the name.

169
00:09:29.990 --> 00:09:31.781
Very cool.
Let's exit out of this and

170
00:09:31.781 --> 00:09:33.687
we'll run it one more time.

171
00:09:33.687 --> 00:09:39.500
And we see now we get success just
by changing that boolean operator.

172
00:09:39.500 --> 00:09:43.330
>> And Daniel, each time you did that it
was just really two comparisons, right?

173
00:09:43.330 --> 00:09:45.790
Could we do three or
four or more if we needed?

174
00:09:45.790 --> 00:09:48.683
>> Yeah, you totally can, you can just go
buck wild with it if you feel like it.

175
00:09:48.683 --> 00:09:51.742
Understand, though,
that starts increasing the complexity.

176
00:09:51.742 --> 00:09:54.942
And if you make a mistake
in any one of those things,

177
00:09:54.942 --> 00:09:59.980
that might cause some issues inside
of your script but it's not illegal.

178
00:09:59.980 --> 00:10:03.690
Go for it, just ampersand ampersand,
next text comparison,

179
00:10:03.690 --> 00:10:06.120
ampersand ampersand, next test comparison.

180
00:10:06.120 --> 00:10:09.340
Or pipe pipe, pipe pipe,

181
00:10:09.340 --> 00:10:12.896
So you could have a string of four
conditions that if any one of those

182
00:10:12.896 --> 00:10:15.259
equaled true, you could make that happen.

183
00:10:15.259 --> 00:10:20.011
So it can really help us reign in out code
from getting too crazy with nesting ifs

184
00:10:20.011 --> 00:10:21.672
and things of that nature.

185
00:10:21.672 --> 00:10:26.550
>> Now in these cases, you were doing
pretty simple comparisons, right?

186
00:10:26.550 --> 00:10:28.806
Equals or not equal, that kind of thing.

187
00:10:28.806 --> 00:10:32.232
But I know I've seen examples
where they do more complex math.

188
00:10:32.232 --> 00:10:36.141
And instead of doing it the way you
did it, they used parenthesis markers,

189
00:10:36.141 --> 00:10:38.240
can you tell us a little bit about that?

190
00:10:38.240 --> 00:10:41.749
>> Yeah, that's a great thing to have
brought up because it does happen, and

191
00:10:41.749 --> 00:10:44.104
if you're not aware of it, you're going?

192
00:10:44.104 --> 00:10:48.288
Do I use a parentheses here or
why are these in parentheses and not this?

193
00:10:48.288 --> 00:10:53.930
And those boundaries that we
typically use throughout our scripts,

194
00:10:53.930 --> 00:10:55.880
they do have a purpose.

195
00:10:55.880 --> 00:11:00.270
And with the double parentheses,
the reason that you

196
00:11:00.270 --> 00:11:03.900
would wanna use the double parentheses is
just the same reason that Don brought up,

197
00:11:03.900 --> 00:11:07.170
is the fact that you have
a more advanced math formula.

198
00:11:08.550 --> 00:11:10.380
Test only allows for simple math, so

199
00:11:10.380 --> 00:11:15.160
if I put those square brackets on, it's
only gonna allow me to do simple stuff.

200
00:11:16.260 --> 00:11:18.806
Things like add, subtract,
multiply, divide.

201
00:11:18.806 --> 00:11:20.757
Those are you simple math offerings.

202
00:11:20.757 --> 00:11:24.700
And if I just want to do that,
great, it's good stuff.

203
00:11:24.700 --> 00:11:30.378
But what if I have more complex
elements to my expression?

204
00:11:30.378 --> 00:11:33.447
What if I wanted to do an exponent?

205
00:11:33.447 --> 00:11:34.689
Hm, well guess what?

206
00:11:34.689 --> 00:11:39.593
You would need the double
parentheses to expand your abilities

207
00:11:39.593 --> 00:11:42.378
to work in a mathematical context.

208
00:11:42.378 --> 00:11:48.893
So if you're doing something simple,
5 + 5, 2 + 1, 8 times 10, great.

209
00:11:48.893 --> 00:11:50.835
Use the square brackets all day long.

210
00:11:50.835 --> 00:11:55.212
But if you gotta start working with things
like exponents and other things that we're

211
00:11:55.212 --> 00:11:59.299
gonna take a look at, then you're gonna
need to use those double parentheses.

212
00:11:59.299 --> 00:12:01.837
So let's open up a text file I've created.

213
00:12:01.837 --> 00:12:04.425
Let me clear the screen,
a little clutter gone.

214
00:12:04.425 --> 00:12:11.860
And I'll say, can't double parentheses,

episodes.description:
In this episode, Daniel and Justin take another look
at redirection, this time focusing on Linux File Descriptors for the
purposes of controlling user presented data. Here they will explain
File Descriptors and then show the many ways in which we can
redirect their output in a scripting context.

a little more manageable, right.

510
00:29:47.173 --> 00:29:50.578
I didn't get any of these permission
denies cuz I wasn't allowed into those

511
00:29:50.578 --> 00:29:53.200
things, they just got shoved
out to the bit bucket.

512
00:29:53.200 --> 00:29:59.780
If I cat/dev/null, you notice nothing
comes back, there's nothing there.

513
00:29:59.780 --> 00:30:01.820
So that's how this working.

514
00:30:01.820 --> 00:30:06.480
Another really cool little trick and then
we'll call it a day Justin, is if I wanted

515
00:30:06.480 --> 00:30:11.340
to empty a file, empty the contents of
a file, I could send dev null, all right.

516
00:30:11.340 --> 00:30:14.340
So for programmatically,
I could redirect that way.

517
00:30:14.340 --> 00:30:21.088
I could say cat dev null and
send that to file name.tht, right.

518
00:30:21.088 --> 00:30:24.440
So I hit that and I cat file name .txt.

519
00:30:24.440 --> 00:30:25.330
There's nothing in it.

520
00:30:25.330 --> 00:30:29.410
So if I had a file with a bunch of stuff
in it and I wanted to just wipe it out.

521
00:30:29.410 --> 00:30:34.520
Let's start with a Tabula rasa,
clean slate.

522
00:30:34.520 --> 00:30:35.350
Then I could do that and

523
00:30:35.350 --> 00:30:38.970
I could do that inside my scripts any
time I needed to empty that file out.

524
00:30:38.970 --> 00:30:42.240
It's a nice quick and dirty way to
make that kind of stuff happen.

525
00:30:42.240 --> 00:30:46.890
But as far as file descriptors go and
redirection goes and working with that and

526
00:30:46.890 --> 00:30:51.550
presenting that output in a way that we'd
want, maybe sending to logs, or sent to

527
00:30:51.550 --> 00:30:56.610
the screen in a log, or taking those
errors and just chucking them to the fire.

528
00:30:56.610 --> 00:30:58.630
That's, I think, all I got for
you for guys today.

529
00:30:58.630 --> 00:31:01.050
It should give you a good
handle on working with that and

530
00:31:01.050 --> 00:31:03.990
help your scripts along a little bit when
it comes to presenting that type of data.

531
00:31:03.990 --> 00:31:04.990
>> Well Daniel,

532
00:31:04.990 --> 00:31:08.460
you've definitely highlighted some
subtleties that even I didn't know about.

533
00:31:08.460 --> 00:31:11.450
I was like, wow,
I didn't know you could do that.

534
00:31:11.450 --> 00:31:14.726
That could have helped me cuz I ended
up with some log files, I don't know if

535
00:31:14.726 --> 00:31:17.950
you've ever tried to open a gigabyte
text file in any type of text editor,

536
00:31:17.950 --> 00:31:21.183
it doesn't work, and that was because

537
00:31:21.183 --> 00:31:25.475
And well now based on what you've told me,

538
00:31:25.475 --> 00:31:27.930
I can just grab the things

539

So thank you for that, but we definitely

00:31:31.730 --> 00:31:33.620
coming your way, so stay tuned.

541
00:31:33.620 --> 00:31:36.720

Signing for ITProTV,

episodes.description:
In this episode, Daniel and Justin show you how to control
script execution. Here they will explain and demonstrate running scripts
as background jobs and employing nohup to ensure they run without
interruption. They also tackle changing script priority using nice and
renice. Finally, they look at scheduling script execution with AT.
episodes.title: Script Control
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

Welcome to IVPRO.TV.

2

3

6

7
00:00:16.174 --> 00:00:17.810
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and

00:00:20.352 --> 00:00:23.099
And we're gonna be looking

12
00:00:29.965 --> 00:00:32.190
Mr. Daniel Lowrie,
how are you doing Daniel.

13

>> No, no.

15
00:00:35.639 --> 00:00:38.845
>> [INAUDIBLE] [LAUGH]
>> No, no, we're good.

16
00:00:38.845 --> 00:00:41.556
Listen, I'm a developer, we're gonna
over prime this and under deliver.

17
00:00:41.556 --> 00:00:43.230
We got that, yeah.

18
00:00:43.230 --> 00:00:43.860
[LAUGH]
>> He is right.

19
00:00:43.860 --> 00:00:45.545
We are going to control these scripts,

20
00:00:45.545 --> 00:00:47.801
because it's sometimes
that's what you wanna do.

21
00:00:47.801 --> 00:00:50.642
Not every time when you
get behind a terminal, or

22
00:00:50.642 --> 00:00:55.302
have a script that you've worked out that
you wanna go, I wanna run this and go.

23
00:00:55.302 --> 00:00:57.570
I wanna run this and go.

24
00:00:57.570 --> 00:00:59.980
Maybe I want it to run at a certain time,

25
00:00:59.980 --> 00:01:04.420
maybe I want it to run at a regular
interval things like that.

26
00:01:04.420 --> 00:01:08.790
And we also want to control the script
as far as maybe it's a priority.

27
00:01:08.790 --> 00:01:13.740
Maybe I need this script to have more
system resources than this script.

28
00:01:13.740 --> 00:01:15.580
How do we do that?

29
00:01:15.580 --> 00:01:17.342
Things of that nature,
that's what we're gonna look at today.

30
00:01:17.342 --> 00:01:20.083
That's what we're talking about
when we say script control.

31
00:01:20.083 --> 00:01:23.209
We're gonna take little more
of a hands on approach,

32
00:01:23.209 --> 00:01:26.130
to making sure that it goes
the way we need it to go.

33
00:01:27.340 --> 00:01:34.234
So let's start with talking about just how
scripts, what scripts do when we run them.

34
00:01:34.234 --> 00:01:39.437
If you run a script, if I open a terminal,
and I run a script, and let's say that

35
00:01:39.437 --> 00:01:45.360
script is waiting for input or it's a lot
of processing of many different things.

36
00:01:45.360 --> 00:01:50.150
If I do that script, then it's gonna
take my terminal away for one thing,

37
00:01:50.150 --> 00:01:53.650
that's one of the biggest problems
with running scripts this way.

38
00:01:53.650 --> 00:01:56.218
And sometimes,
they can hijack the terminal and

39
00:01:56.218 --> 00:01:58.460
you've gotta open up another one.

40
00:01:58.460 --> 00:02:03.020
There's a couple of ways around that from
happening, and we did talk a bit about

41
00:02:03.020 --> 00:02:08.940
that in the Linux command line basics,
but I wanna revisit that a little bit,

42
00:02:08.940 --> 00:02:12.670
and then use that as a springboard
going to some more advance stuff.

43
00:02:12.670 --> 00:02:15.500
So let's talk about that,
how are we gonna get our terminal back?

44
00:02:15.500 --> 00:02:21.330
Well, we can always use the ampersand
at the end of our script command.

45
00:02:21.330 --> 00:02:26.130
So if I do, ./scripts, and
then put an ampersand at the end,

46
00:02:26.130 --> 00:02:28.220
a space and an ampersand.

47
00:02:28.220 --> 00:02:31.370
It will say, you want me to
run that as a background job.

48
00:02:31.370 --> 00:02:34.970
So put that in the background,
give me my terminal back and

49
00:02:34.970 --> 00:02:39.700
I continue on my merry way,
banging out whatever, playing Sudoku.

50
00:02:39.700 --> 00:02:44.500
But, I've gotta remember that that's
how I've created that background job.

51
00:02:45.960 --> 00:02:49.740
So let's see how that works out,
let's do that, just so

52
00:02:49.740 --> 00:02:52.550
that we can move our progression.

53
00:02:52.550 --> 00:02:58.650
So if I say ./script.sh, like that,
I throw an ampersand on the end.

54
00:02:58.650 --> 00:03:03.027
I hit Enter, there we go, you'll notice
that this thing pops up right here.

55
00:03:05.032 --> 00:03:08.360
Actually, I don't care, let me see here,
maybe I'm gonna script one,

56
00:03:08.360 --> 00:03:10.370
there's my problem.

57
00:03:10.370 --> 00:03:14.710
Let's try running the right script first,
and then we'll see what that does.

58
00:03:14.710 --> 00:03:19.739
There we go, and it still gets
the same kind of to begin with,

59
00:03:19.739 --> 00:03:23.223
which is you get this number 1 and 24332.

60
00:03:23.223 --> 00:03:26.838
And you recall, that's its PID,
its process ID,

61
00:03:26.838 --> 00:03:30.325
it's got a job that's happening,
if I do jobs.

62
00:03:30.325 --> 00:03:34.250
[LAUGH]
I am a horrible typist.

63
00:03:34.250 --> 00:03:38.480
There we go, jobs, we see that
it is running in the background.

64
00:03:38.480 --> 00:03:40.870
But I kept my terminal open,
I can throw the commands at it.

65
00:03:40.870 --> 00:03:44.900
If I wanted to bring it to the foreground,
I do fg, and I can do that.

66
00:03:45.900 --> 00:03:50.640
I could do jobs percents one for
the job number.

67
00:03:51.720 --> 00:03:52.280
I can work with that.

68
00:03:52.280 --> 00:03:56.284
Remember, that was from what Donn was
showing us back in that command line show.

69
00:03:56.284 --> 00:04:00.322
And it's great stuff,
good control, stuff that we like.

70
00:04:00.322 --> 00:04:04.820
There are some caveats
to doing it this way.

71
00:04:04.820 --> 00:04:07.800
One of the caveats is,
if I close this terminal down.

72
00:04:07.800 --> 00:04:13.010
Guess what's happened to that background
process, it's done, it kills it.

73
00:04:13.010 --> 00:04:16.820
And the reason is that, it's because those
jobs are tied to that terminal sessions.

74
00:04:16.820 --> 00:04:18.930
When the terminal dies, the job dies.

75
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:24.090
And, what if there's no terminal open,
and I still need to run a job,

76
00:04:24.090 --> 00:04:28.010
I need to spawn a session so that it can.

77
00:04:28.010 --> 00:04:29.470
Jobs isn't really gonna
help me out with that,

78
00:04:29.470 --> 00:04:31.870
so we're gonna have to move on
from there for those things.

79
00:04:31.870 --> 00:04:35.180
But working with jobs,
that is something that can happen.

80
00:04:35.180 --> 00:04:40.270
So if I wanna stick inside this vein,
I can send it a signal and say,

81
00:04:41.490 --> 00:04:47.830
even if you kill this terminal session,
I don't want my background process to die.

82
00:04:47.830 --> 00:04:51.241
So when you spawn the background process,

83
00:04:51.241 --> 00:04:55.230
I want you to do it in
a detached terminal session.

84
00:04:55.230 --> 00:04:56.950
So that it's no longer
attached to this one.

85
00:04:56.950 --> 00:05:00.240
That way I can kill my terminal,
and my job continues to run.

86
00:05:02.120 --> 00:05:03.190
So how do we do that?

87
00:05:03.190 --> 00:05:04.480
Like I said, we send it a signal,

88
00:05:04.480 --> 00:05:08.990
there are many different signals found
inside of the Linux operating system.

89
00:05:08.990 --> 00:05:10.220
One of them is no hub.

90
00:05:11.530 --> 00:05:13.550
So if we send,
which stands for a no hang up.

91
00:05:14.680 --> 00:05:18.290
So it means I don't want to, you're gonna
think of it, I think of it is no hang up.

92
00:05:18.290 --> 00:05:23.570
I'm on the phone, and Justin starts
having a conversation with me,

93
00:05:23.570 --> 00:05:26.600
I could hang up the phone and
now I'm doing that job.

94
00:05:26.600 --> 00:05:32.210
Now I'm having a conversation with Justin,
but if I wanna kind of put them on hold.

95
00:05:32.210 --> 00:05:35.030
I say, well,
I'm not gonna hang up, no hangup.

96
00:05:35.030 --> 00:05:37.180
Still have this conversation alive,

97
00:05:38.360 --> 00:05:41.750
I just might not be working
with it in the foreground.

98
00:05:41.750 --> 00:05:44.820
And if I stop talking to Justin
that conversation is still there,

99
00:05:44.820 --> 00:05:47.510
it's kind of detached
from what's going on.

100
00:05:47.510 --> 00:05:52.160
So, if we want to detach our job from
the terminal that it was spawned in,

101
00:05:52.160 --> 00:05:57.443
then we've gotta use that KNOW Hub signal,
so see how that works itself out here.

102
00:05:57.443 --> 00:06:02.271
So if I say Know Hub like that, and

103
00:06:02.271 --> 00:06:08.135
then I give it the ./script 11.sh,

104
00:06:08.135 --> 00:06:13.530
and I throw in the background.

105
00:06:13.530 --> 00:06:17.560
I hit Enter, there we go, and
you'll notice it says ignoring input,

106
00:06:17.560 --> 00:06:21.270
appending output to knowhub.out.

107
00:06:21.270 --> 00:06:25.550
So whenever the script runs or if there's
any errors or something like that,

108
00:06:25.550 --> 00:06:29.300
it will go to knowhub.out, because it's
no longer attached to this terminal.

109
00:06:29.300 --> 00:06:33.720
Standard out is not here,
now it's basically standard out

110
00:06:33.720 --> 00:06:38.190
scenario are going to Know Hub, so
let me see if I get my terminal back.

111
00:06:38.190 --> 00:06:42.470
So very cool, so if you need to do that,
that was a really good way to make sure

112
00:06:42.470 --> 00:06:47.035
that any job that you respond, even though
you put it in the background doesn't die.

113
00:06:47.035 --> 00:06:51.240
Cuz god knows I've done it where you throw
a java background, you bang away at your

114
00:06:51.240 --> 00:06:54.260
keyboards, doing all this stuff
you're like okay I'm done, exit.

115
00:06:54.260 --> 00:06:56.901
[SOUND] Fatal flaw, big mistake,

116
00:06:56.901 --> 00:07:01.532
I just killed my background process,
so be aware of that.

117
00:07:01.532 --> 00:07:02.167
>> Now Daniel,

118
00:07:02.167 --> 00:07:05.919
would this also work if let's say I was
running a kind of a maintenance job, or

119
00:07:05.919 --> 00:07:09.350
a maintenance script, or
whatever it may be in an ssh session?

120
00:07:09.350 --> 00:07:12.230
Could I do this and
get out of the ssh session or

121
00:07:12.230 --> 00:07:16.130
is this strictly, I'm not entirely sure,
because, is there something where I'm like

122
00:07:16.130 --> 00:07:18.730
I need to get into this remote server,
do some things.

123
00:07:18.730 --> 00:07:21.930
Let this run,
I don't need to stay connected via ssh.

124
00:07:21.930 --> 00:07:23.710
Let me get out, would this work for that?

125
00:07:23.710 --> 00:07:27.580
>> Yes it would, because it's detaching
it off from that ssh session.

126
00:07:27.580 --> 00:07:30.400
Saying I've got a process,
I'm gonna throw it in the background, and

127
00:07:30.400 --> 00:07:35.020
I'm gonna give it its own terminal,
its own shell to run in.

128
00:07:35.020 --> 00:07:38.368
This ssh session shell that you're
working in, that's detached from that.

129
00:07:38.368 --> 00:07:40.913
So you continue to bang away and
do whatever you want, or

130
00:07:40.913 --> 00:07:44.690
exit out from it and you're still,
you should still be running fine.

131
00:07:44.690 --> 00:07:49.635
And so, that's what Know Hub does,
it says, do not hang up this process,

132
00:07:49.635 --> 00:07:53.649
I need it to run regardless of
what happens to this terminal.

133
00:07:53.649 --> 00:07:56.714
So a great way to make that happen.

134
00:07:56.714 --> 00:08:00.937
All right,
let's start talking about script priority.

135
00:08:00.937 --> 00:08:05.220
This gets fun, right,
it's a lot of good times here.

136
00:08:05.220 --> 00:08:07.299
Let me see, I wanna make sure I don't
have any jobs running, yeah, I do.

137
00:08:07.299 --> 00:08:11.975
Alt-A, F-G.

138
00:08:11.975 --> 00:08:13.525
Well how about that.

139
00:08:13.525 --> 00:08:15.854
F-G percent 1.

140
00:08:15.854 --> 00:08:16.950
Here we go, no such step.

141
00:08:16.950 --> 00:08:17.450
Okay, great.

142
00:08:18.810 --> 00:08:20.170
Yeah, great, they're done [LAUGH].

143
00:08:20.170 --> 00:08:23.800
I was just making sure I didn't have
any rogue processes running there.

144
00:08:23.800 --> 00:08:26.330
So I've got scripts.

145
00:08:26.330 --> 00:08:29.540
I've got some scripts that
need a little more umph.

146
00:08:30.880 --> 00:08:31.930
I got some scripts that don't.

147
00:08:33.060 --> 00:08:34.542
You get to it, you get to it.

148
00:08:34.542 --> 00:08:36.519
You do something, you do something.

149
00:08:36.519 --> 00:08:41.820
How do I tell the system this
needs priority, more priority.

150
00:08:41.820 --> 00:08:44.771
And this needs less priority.

151
00:08:44.771 --> 00:08:47.540
And the way we can do that is
through a lovely little command.

152
00:08:47.540 --> 00:08:50.166
It's so beautiful, it's called nice.

153
00:08:50.166 --> 00:08:52.453
It's called being nice.

154
00:08:52.453 --> 00:08:54.280
It's some interesting, fun stuff.

155
00:08:57.190 --> 00:08:59.848
I was explaining this to
Justin before the show.

156
00:08:59.848 --> 00:09:03.730
It's gonna kinda freak you out for
a second because when we talk about

157
00:09:03.730 --> 00:09:07.830
priorities, specifically CPU priority,
how much CPU should I give this?

158
00:09:07.830 --> 00:09:09.630
How much should I not give it?

159
00:09:09.630 --> 00:09:11.080
And it's a little backwards,

160
00:09:11.080 --> 00:09:14.730
it does the opposite most likely
of what you think it should do.

161
00:09:15.740 --> 00:09:20.530
So when you spot a process,
it gets a CPU priority of zero,

162
00:09:21.590 --> 00:09:27.826
and this is kinda like the neutral ground,
the dead center, the middle, okay?

163
00:09:27.826 --> 00:09:33.160
If I want it to be more priority, Justin,
which way do you think it would go?

164
00:09:33.160 --> 00:09:35.668
>> My gut instinct is you go up for
more priority and you go down for

165
00:09:35.668 --> 00:09:36.351
less priority.

166
00:09:36.351 --> 00:09:40.894
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I,

167
00:09:40.894 --> 00:09:45.720
I'm not sure if that's,
if my gut is telling me right in this.

168
00:09:45.720 --> 00:09:49.010
>> And he's right, like,
your common logic and

169
00:09:49.010 --> 00:09:52.160
common sense would say,
numbers work this way.

170
00:09:52.160 --> 00:09:54.910
The bigger the number,
the more of something you get.

171
00:09:54.910 --> 00:09:57.030
The smaller the number,
the less of something you get.

172
00:09:57.030 --> 00:10:00.870
And if you go down into the negatives
it's even, you're in a deficit now.

173
00:10:00.870 --> 00:10:03.900
It's even less than zero.

174
00:10:03.900 --> 00:10:06.200
Right, so what's nice, though.

175
00:10:06.200 --> 00:10:08.590
It's, flip that idea around in your head.

176
00:10:08.590 --> 00:10:11.412
Get it like that and go all 180.

177
00:10:11.412 --> 00:10:12.970
And now that's how it works.

178
00:10:12.970 --> 00:10:18.220
So if we start off with that zero, we have
a range of priorities that we can use.

179
00:10:18.220 --> 00:10:24.040
Starting from the highest being negative
20 and the lowest being positive 19.

180
00:10:24.040 --> 00:10:29.340
So minus 20 to plus 19,
plus 19 being the lowest.

181
00:10:29.340 --> 00:10:32.990
I know you're gonna make the mistake,
I almost guarantee it though.
